subject: Create missing domains during Bind9Backend start
commit_message:
Create missing domains during Bind9Backend start

The Bind9Backend start function uses rndc to reload each domain.  If a
domain is missing on the Bind9 server, a ProcessExecutionError will be
raised.  This bug was recreated by stopping a bind9 process, deleting
the cached nzf files in /var/cache/bind, and restarting the process.
The Designate Central service was then restarted, and the bug triggered.

The original bug report requested that the Bind9Backend check for zones
on the server before trying to reload them, but rndc does not appear to
support that operation.

A less ideal approach is used:  the start function will now catch
ProcessExecutionError exceptions and issue a command to recreate the
zone if the caught exception indicates that the zone was not found.

Another alternative approach could use standard DNS query tools rather
than rndc to confirm zone existence.

Change-Id: Id164392f2419fc88257b9f21c1d0ef723280a8b6
Closes-Bug: #1271493

subject: Use Emacs-friendly file variable to set file encoding
commit_message:
Use Emacs-friendly file variable to set file encoding

Like Python, Emacs can read the file encoding from the first two
lines. Python will accept a line with

  -*- encoding: <some-encoding> -*-

since it looks for containing "coding:" or "coding=" (PEP 263) and
allows substring matches. Emacs only accepts

  -*- coding: <some-encoding> -*-

since it looks for a file variable named "coding", not "encoding":

  https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Specify-Coding.html

Setting a variable called "encoding" has at best no effect, but it can
result in Emacs prompting the user with

  The local variable list in __init__.py contains values that may not
  be safe.

when opening the file. This is because the "encoding" variable is not
whitelisted as a safe variable.

The command used to update the files were:

  sed -i '1,2s/-\*- encoding:/-*- coding:/' **/*.py

This accounts for the case where the file variables is set in the
second line because the first line is used for a "#!" line.

Change-Id: I29f6796357fe8b7f3332184365cdcea43070b434

subject: auth_token middleware hashes tokens with configurable algorithm
commit_message:
auth_token middleware hashes tokens with configurable algorithm

The auth_token middleware always hashed PKI Tokens with MD5. This
change makes it so that PKI tokens can be hashed with SHA256 or any
other algorithm supported by hashlib.new(). This is for security
hardening.

auth_token has a new config option 'hash_algorithms' that is set
to the list of algorithms that will be used for hashing PKI tokens.
This will typically be set to a single hash algorithm which must
match the hash algorithm set in Keystone. Otherwise the tokens
in the revocation list will not match, leading to revoked tokens
being still usable.

During a transition from one algorithm to another,
'hash_algorithms' is set to both the new algorithm and the old
algorithm. Both of the hash algorithms will be used to match
against the revocation list and cache. Once the tokens using the
old algorithm have expired the old algorithm can be removed from
the list.

'hash_algorithms' defaults to ['md5'] for backwards compatibility.

DocImpact
SecurityImpact
Closes-Bug: #1174499

subject: Set onlink routes for all subnets on an external network
commit_message:
Set onlink routes for all subnets on an external network

The addition of the on-link routes gives us some freedom to allocate a
router's IP address from any one of multiple subnets on one external
network.  Different routers can get their IPs from different subnets and
they still have direct on-link connectivity to each other.  For example,
one router with its primary IP from 10.0.0.0/24 and another from
192.168.0.0/24 can communicate directly.  It is important that each
router has on-link routes to *all* of the subnets.

Any router can host floating ips from any of the subnets regardless of
which subnet the primary IP address comes from.

This is an alternative to the "Multiple floating IP pools" section in
the administration guide.  It is a simpler alternative that avoids
having to create multiple external networks.  It is also more flexible
because routers will no longer be restricted to getting floating IPs
from the pool to which they happen to be connected.

DocImpact
Document the procedure for adding subnets to the external network.
Potentially remove the existing procedure for "Multiple floating IP
pools" from the docs.

Change-Id: I2c283f5be0cbb6b5d350cafc1b636c300b796a7b

subject: Nasty hack to work around pip's case-sensitivity
commit_message:
Nasty hack to work around pip's case-sensitivity

When pip is using an index url that uses http:// or https://, it will
respond to a 404 by searching a bit harder for variantCase versions of
the package name. This is very handy, results in pip appearing to be
case insensitive, and is relied on by many packages which simply specify
their dependencies in all lowercase regardless of the actual case of the
package.

When the index url uses file:// instead, no exception is handled -
instead the script simply dies once it fails to stat a file on disk.

This is only needed until
https://github.com/jamezpolley/pip/compare/pypa:develop...develop lands
upstream in pip. That patch adds an exception handler which catches the
fail to stat and generates a 404 Response object, which lets the same
handling code that triggers in the http:// case handle failures in the
file:// case as well.

We first hit this problem because of the MarkupSafe package being
specified as markupsafe in Jinja2's requirements.txt. This has been
fixed in
https://github.com/mitsuhiko/jinja2/commit/70a2bc0e58c211bdd86e89abd29ec12b2387b6fa#diff-2eeaed663bd0d25b7e608891384b7298
but this change does not seem to have been released yet.

This doesn't even approach a sensible fix; but since we expect the
problem to be fixed upstream shortly; and since this is the only known
occurrence of this problem (to me at least), this is a tiny little hack
that gets us out of a temporary bind and will be trivial to revert.

Closes bug: #1301220

Change-Id: I013d2bddfb275f0b0248e5498cd84fe251ef7070

subject: Move watch task out of worker process
commit_message:
Move watch task out of worker process

The periodic watch task start_watch_task for each stack is performed
after the fork when running multiple worker processes, which is
probably not what we want, instead create the watch task in the
constructor (which is called before the fork).  Testing indicates
we only end up with one timer fired due to the common StackWatch
and ThreadGroupManager, but creating the tasks per engine instead
of per worker makes more logical sense.

Also adds a periodic_enable config option, which allows periodic
tasks to be completely disabled.  This is left defaulted to True
for now, but should be set to False for all multi-engine deployments
to avoid stacks with watch rules having multiple periodic tasks
which race to evaluate/action alarms, which is unlikely to work as
StackWatch doesn't use the global stack lock.

This is the first step to deprecating periodic tasks/watch rules
(we can probably default periodic_enable to False after we make the
ceilometer based AWS::CloudWatch::Alarm implementation the default
intead of CWLite, currently blocked on bug #1316842)

subject: Fix logging setup for Python 3.4
commit_message:
Fix logging setup for Python 3.4

The logging.getLevelName is supposed to be used to get string
representation from integer code, not vice versa. It is possible to get
int code from the string using this function in Python 2, but not in
Python 3.4, where for example getLevelName('DEBUG') will return
'Level DEBUG' instead of 10.
Only in Python2.6, Logger.setLevel doesn't do automatic

subject: Enforce unicode json output for jsonutils.load[s]()
commit_message:
Enforce unicode json output for jsonutils.load[s]()

simplejson module applies some optimizations on ASCII-only unicode
strings which result in non-unicode json output. See details at [1]
and [2]. To make sure we always return consistent json output no
matter which json implementation is used, we should explicitly convert
the input for json.load[s]() to unicode.

If user wants to pass a file object of non UTF-8 encoding to
json.load[s](), she must also specify this encoding as an argument. To
support this scenario too, we've added 'encoding' argument to
jsonutils.load[s]() implementation.

Made all present JSON tests to run on both supported json library
implementations.

Added explicit dependency for simplejson to be able to test different
implementations in unit tests. Distributors still running Python 2.6
are recommended but not required to install simplejson.

Related-Bug: 1314129

[1]: https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/11742
[2]: https://code.google.com/p/simplejson/issues/detail?id=40

subject: vmware: Fix problems with VIM API retry logic
commit_message:
vmware: Fix problems with VIM API retry logic

Currently the VIM APIs including session creation API are retried for
cases which are unrelated to connection or session overload problems.
This change fix the retry logic as follows:
* Add an exception to indicate connection problem and raise it
  appropriately from the VIM API client
* Modify the expected exceptions in the retry decorator to include
  only connection and session overload related exceptions

This change also fixes the base class of VimFaultException
(VolumeBackendAPIException -> VimException). This change is required
so that we can handle the exceptions thrown by the VIM API client in
a consistent manner. Currently if we need to handle VIM API related
exceptions, we have to catch both VimException and VimFaultException.
For example, the API for checking active session raises
VimFaultException in some cases and we are handling only VimException.
Due to this, when session expires, the session re-establishment and API
retry fails (intermittently) since the check for active session throws
VimFaultException in some cases which is not handled.

subject: Make selenium tests more robust
commit_message:
Make selenium tests more robust

The selenium tests are often hanging in the gate due to rogue
'firefox -silent' processes. Borrow a fix from SST that overrides
the default Firefox WebDriver so it doesn't spawn the processes in the
first place.

There's also a ~10% timeout failure in the qunit/jasmine tests.
Make sure the default socket timeout is set early enough so
the initial selenium/testserver setup doesn't occasionally fail on the
first test of a test case. This gets it down to around 5% failure rate.

Also wrap each test case in a sleep() sandwich to give services time to
settle before the tests start. This isn't ideal as it makes the tests
take longer, but with this change I finally get no false negatives at all
over 100+ runs.

Closes-bug: 1317630

commit: I6b8e2ba2b7e78fa280283d5ee82d618d4f44ec5a
Author: Zu Qiang
Date: Thu May 22 11:35:00 2014 -0500
Implements: bugfix BUGFIX
Closes-Bug: 1291111/1322200
Reason of the change: The installation will be failure if the network
proxy is set. The reason of the failure is that any REST request sent
to the installed OpenStack itself will be redirected to the proxy
server. By default, the no_proxy is set to localhost only, which needs
to be reset to the localhost + HOST_IP + FLOATING_RANG + FIXED_RANGE.

Changes:

 Add "call export_no_proxy_variables" in stack.sh
     This is used to reset the no_proxy variable after HOST_IP,
FLOATING_RANG, FIXED_RANGE have been set.
     # Reset no_porxy variables
     export_no_proxy_variables

 Add a new function "export_no_proxy_variables" in function_common
The new function will reset the no_proxy variable. And save it in the
shell configuration file. It also creates a new file "noproxy".
The noproxy file will be used by other installation procedure,
e.g. Trove.
   # Update no proxy environment variables
   # no_proxy is set in $USERHOME/.bashrc and $USERHOME/noproxy
   #
   function export_no_proxy_variables {
       export no_proxy=`echo $no_proxy,$HOST_IP,$FLOATING_RANG,$FIXED_RANGE | sed -e 's/,\+/,/g'`
     # Check if the USERHOME is set
       if [[ -z "$USERHOME" ]]; then
           USERHOME=$HOME
       fi
     # Save the no_proxy configuration in the shell rc
       if [[ -n `grep 'no_proxy' $USERHOME/.bashrc` ]]; then
          sed -i "/no_proxy=/c\no_proxy=$no_proxy" $USERHOME/.bashrc
       else
          echo -e "# Reset the no_proxy variables\nno_proxy="$no_proxy >> $USERHOME/.bashrc
       fi
     # Recreating no_proxy file
       echo no_proxy=$no_proxy > $USERHOME/noproxy
       chmod +x $USERHOME/noproxy
   }

Change-Id: I6b8e2ba2b7e78fa280283d5ee82d618d4f44ec5a

Current code does not allow assigning a fixed ip to a port when that ip

want to allow addresses in 10.10.1.0/24 cidr on that port, then one
has to configure a list of 8 cidrs ([10.10.1.0/32, 10.10.1.2/31,
10.10.1.4/30, ..., 10.10.1.128/25]) on the allowed-addresspairs.
In addition to the above reasons, the current code also does not
check for the overlaps in all cases.
